name: The Marine Biolicical Association of the United Kingdom
membership: The MBA is a member of the Royal Society of Biology (http://www.rsb.org.uk/), Euromarine (http://www.euromarineconsortium.eu/), the European Network of Marine Research Institutes and Stations, MARS (http://www.marsnetwork.org/) the Partnership for Observation of the Global Oceans, POGO (http://www.ocean-partners.org/) and the European Marine Biological Resource Centre, EMBRC (http://www.embrc.eu/).
goal:
The charitable aims of the Marine Biological Association (MBA) are to promote scientific research into all aspects of life in the sea, including the environment on which it depends, and to disseminate to the public the knowledge gained.

The MBA was founded in 1884 and in 1888 opened the Plymouth laboratory at Citadel Hill. The MBA provides a unified, clear, independent voice on behalf of the marine biological community.
interests: Communication, Education and training, Environment, Maritime affairs and fisheries, Research and innovation, Trans-European Networks
euInitiatives:
The MBA is interested in all areas of policy relating to Marine Biology and the marine environment.

The MBA has had significant input into the development and implementation of marine legislation such as the Marine Strategy Framework Directive and the marine elements of the Habitats Directive.

General areas of interest include Education, Environment, Fisheries and aquaculture, Research and technology, data and Trans-European networks.
